conclusion: Objects A and B are released above the tabletop.
Gravity pulls each of them straight down until they touch the tabletop and the solid blocks already standing there (C & D on the left, E & F on the right).
As soon as contact occurs, each descending sheet (A or B) is stopped by the blocks.
On the left, the yellow (C) and the red (D) prisms prop up the fabric, so A drapes across their tops and then sags to the table between and around them.
On the right, the two green prisms (E is shorter, F is taller) do the same, so B stretches over the taller prism first, then over the shorter one, and finally sags to the table.

Friction between cloth and blocks prevents the sheets from sliding off; the cloth settles into a stable draped shape with visible bulges directly above each block and a sagging valley in the open spaces.
Once the motion stops, both sheets remain motionless, partly supported by the blocks and partly lying flat on the tabletop.
Each sheet (A and B) drapes over its corresponding pair of blocks (C–D and E–F), producing two separate cloth-covered mounds that mirror the height and position of the blocks beneath them.
